text.p: These are significant stories in the Nigerian press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Bomb blasts in Lagos trigger new security measures with detectives posted to public buildings; Nigerians condemn the explosions as grand design to destabilise nation and derail current transition to democracy programme.
- A total of 293 condemned prisoners are awaiting execution in the southeastern Akwa Ibom state, says state military administrator Navy Captain Joseph Adeusi.
- New investors may take over four ailing banks under a fresh move to make them viable, central bank sources said.
- Nigerian joint venture with Chevron Corp budgets $310 million to upgrade their oil production facilities.
- Military and police chiefs hold marathon meeting in Lagos in effort to unravel culprits of recent bomb blasts in Lagos.
- Budget 1997 may not be broadcast on Friday as widely expected because only one of the four high level meetings to approve it has been held so far.
- Stock exchange halts trading in shares of British American Insurance Company because of audit query on its accounts.
- General cargo ship, Hamilton, docks in Lagos with more than 10,000 tonnes of rice, first such consignment this year.
- Victim of bomb attack on army bus in Lagos delivers baby girl at military hospital where she was taken for treatment.
- Government of neighbouring Benin denies impounding arms and ammunition imported by Nigerian opposition and heading for the country as alleged by Nigerian state television in recent report.
- Private Nigerian oil firm Mennoil signs pact with Chinese institute for design and installation of technical processes for lubricants and chemicals produced by the company.
